articles.headline: 2 Banks Cited in Stress Tests Find Ready Investors
articles.snippet: Wells Fargo and Morgan Stanley quickly raised more than $15 billion between them, easing concerns about luring private investors to recapitalize the banks.
articles.abstract: Wells Fargo and Morgan Stanley quickly raised more than $15 billion between them, easing concerns about luring private investors to recapitalize the banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Finally, it was a moment for the banks to de-stress.

articles.headline: For Somali Pirates, Worst Enemy May Be on Shore
articles.snippet: Somalia’s pirates are the targets not just of those they attack, but also of sheiks and elders who are fed up with their vices.
articles.abstract: Somalia’s pirates are the targets not just of those they attack, but also of sheiks and elders who are fed up with their vices.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAROOWE, Somalia — Abshir Boyah, a towering, notorious Somali pirate boss who admits to hijacking more than 25 ships and to being a member of a secretive pirate council called “The Corporation,” says he’s ready to cut a deal.

articles.headline: Fine Line for Obama on How to Convey Hope on Economy
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is trying, carefully, to renew confidence among the public without declaring victory too soon.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is trying, carefully, to renew confidence among the public without declaring victory too soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The formula for restoring national confidence  part good policy, part good politics, part good luck  can be hard to find. It eluded Herbert Hoover after the Crash of ’29, Lyndon B. Johnson after the Tet offensive, Jimmy Carter after the energy shock and George W. Bush after Iraq turned from quick victory to bloody insurgency.

articles.headline: New York and London: Twins in Finance and Folly
articles.snippet: If stricter regulations are imposed on British banks, the decisions will probably have to start in the U.S.
articles.abstract: If stricter regulations are imposed on British banks, the decisions will probably have to start in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: London

articles.headline: The Hidden Peril of Deferred-Compensation Plans
articles.snippet: Salary set aside by highly paid workers in accounts to lessen tax burdens would almost certainly be lost if your employer were to file for bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: Salary set aside by highly paid workers in accounts to lessen tax burdens would almost certainly be lost if your employer were to file for bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not frightened enough by the dwindling balance in your retirement accounts in the last year?

articles.headline: Adroit Envoy States Case for Pakistan
articles.snippet: Husain Haqqani, Pakistan’s ambassador to the U.S. and a lucid interpreter of his country’s politics, has become influential in Washington.
articles.abstract: Husain Haqqani, Pakistan’s ambassador to the U.S. and a lucid interpreter of his country’s politics, has become influential in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  On May 4, 1999, Husain Haqqani was yanked off a Pakistani street and bundled into a car, a blanket thrown over his head. He managed to keep his cellphone hidden in his pocket, and surreptitiously dialed a friend’s number to let her know he was in trouble.

articles.headline: Flu? What Flu?
articles.snippet: With 8 percent of the Mexican economy based on tourism, the flu epidemic has been a disaster. But Mexico’s government is trying to lure tourists back.
articles.abstract: With 8 percent of the Mexican economy based on tourism, the flu epidemic has been a disaster. But Mexico’s government is trying to lure tourists back.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY  If you are looking for a cheap travel destination, try Mexico.

articles.headline: Hospitals Pay for Cutting Costly Readmissions
articles.snippet: Readmitted patients cost the government billions, but hospitals that curb return trips are not rewarded.
articles.abstract: Readmitted patients cost the government billions, but hospitals that curb return trips are not rewarded.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is one of the biggest avoidable costs on the nation’s medical bill.

articles.headline: Shift to Saving May Be Downturn’s Lasting Impact
articles.snippet: The recession is forcing a return to a culture of thrift that many economists say could last well beyond the recovery.
articles.abstract: The recession is forcing a return to a culture of thrift that many economists say could last well beyond the recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economic downturn is forcing a return to a culture of thrift that many economists say could last well beyond the inevitable recovery.

articles.headline: Parks Fortify Israel’s Claim to Jerusalem
articles.snippet: A $100 million effort to develop parks outside the Old City of Jerusalem may strengthen Israeli claims to the land.
articles.abstract: A $100 million effort to develop parks outside the Old City of Jerusalem may strengthen Israeli claims to the land.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Israel is quietly carrying out a $100 million, multiyear development plan in some of the most significant religious and national heritage sites just outside the walled Old City here as part of an effort to strengthen the status of Jerusalem as its capital.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Free Fall’s Over, but Where Are We Landing?
articles.snippet: The edge of the financial crisis appears to have dulled, but in Boise, Idaho, and the rest of the nation, the economy remains weak and the future uncertain.
articles.abstract: The edge of the financial crisis appears to have dulled, but in Boise, Idaho, and the rest of the nation, the economy remains weak and the future uncertain.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOISE, Idaho

articles.headline: For Victims of Recession, Patchwork State Aid
articles.snippet: As millions of Americans seek aid, many are finding it dispensed through a jumble of disconnected programs that reach some and reject others.
articles.abstract: As millions of Americans seek aid, many are finding it dispensed through a jumble of disconnected programs that reach some and reject others.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As millions of people seek government aid, many for the first time, they are finding it dispensed American style: through a jumble of disconnected programs that reach some and reject others, often for reasons of geography or chance rather than differences in need.

articles.headline: Stress Tests Are Over. The Stress Isn’t.
articles.snippet: It would be a relief to move on from the financial crisis, but we can’t conclude that the nation’s big banks are out of the woods.
articles.abstract: It would be a relief to move on from the financial crisis, but we can’t conclude that the nation’s big banks are out of the woods.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE beginning of the end of the banking crisis or merely the end of the beginning?

articles.headline: Backlash: Women Bullying Women at Work
articles.snippet: It’s a taboo topic in the workplace sisterhood: Women who bully usually pick on other women.
articles.abstract: It’s a taboo topic in the workplace sisterhood: Women who bully usually pick on other women.
articles.lead_paragraph: YELLING, scheming and sabotaging: all are tell-tale signs that a bully is at work, laying traps for employees at every pass.

articles.headline: Banks Brace for Credit Card Write-Offs
articles.snippet: Even the grim projections may vastly understate the size of the credit card troubles in store for major U.S. banks.
articles.abstract: Even the grim projections may vastly understate the size of the credit card troubles in store for major U.S. banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: It used to be easy to guess how many Americans would have problems paying their credit card bills. Banks just looked at unemployment: Fewer jobs meant more trouble ahead.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: China Outpaces U.S. in Cleaner Coal-Fired Plants
articles.snippet: While Americans debate the use of so-called clean coal, China is mastering the application of the technology.
articles.abstract: While Americans debate the use of so-called clean coal, China is mastering the application of the technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China  China’s frenetic construction of coal-fired power plants has raised worries around the world about the effect on climate change. China now uses more coal than the United States, Europe and Japan combined, making it the world’s largest emitter of gases that are warming the planet.

articles.headline: Separation of Press and State
articles.snippet: Government help for the news industry would hobble the free press model. Painful as it is, newspapers must stand or fall on their own.
articles.abstract: Government help for the news industry would hobble the free press model. Painful as it is, newspapers must stand or fall on their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: So it’s come to this: Even the president of the United States feels sorry for journalists.

articles.headline: Advertising Losses Put Squeeze on TV News
articles.snippet: With lower ad revenue since the presidential election, some outlets are looking to pool resources in a variety of ways.
articles.abstract: With lower ad revenue since the presidential election, some outlets are looking to pool resources in a variety of ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is getting so bad for local television stations that some are turning to newspapers for help.

articles.headline: Despite Lower Ratings, Cash Flow Rises for ‘Idol’
articles.snippet: Despite losing viewers in each of the last three years, “American Idol” is generating ever-growing profits for its backers through brand extensions, marketing arrangements and licensing fees.
articles.abstract: Despite losing viewers in each of the last three years, “American Idol” is generating ever-growing profits for its backers through brand extensions, marketing arrangements and licensing fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Can a television show with a shrinking audience actually increase its revenue?

articles.headline: Cadets Trade the Trenches for Firewalls
articles.snippet: In cyberwar games conducted by military schools with the National Security Agency, hackers replace snipers.
articles.abstract: In cyberwar games conducted by military schools with the National Security Agency, hackers replace snipers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N.Y. — The Army forces were under attack. Communications were down, and the chain of command was broken.
articles.byline: By Corey Kilgannon and Noam Cohen

articles.headline: Outbreaks Put Worry on the Table
articles.snippet: Experts believe the food supply is safer than in the days before pasteurization and refrigeration, but new dangers have emerged.
articles.abstract: Experts believe the food supply is safer than in the days before pasteurization and refrigeration, but new dangers have emerged.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every few weeks, it seems, deadly germs turn up in the food supply.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Gardiner Harris

articles.headline: Shaky Pakistan Is Seen as Target of Qaeda Plots
articles.snippet: Foreign operatives of Al Qaeda are moving to sow chaos in Pakistan and strengthen the hand of the militant Islamist groups there, U.S. and Pakistani intelligence officials say.
articles.abstract: Foreign operatives of Al Qaeda are moving to sow chaos in Pakistan and strengthen the hand of the militant Islamist groups there, U.S. and Pakistani intelligence officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As Taliban militants push deeper into Pakistan’s settled areas, foreign operatives of Al Qaeda who had focused on plotting attacks against the West are seizing on the turmoil to sow chaos in Pakistan and strengthen the hand of the militant Islamist groups there, according to American and Pakistani intelligence officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Efficient Power Use Attracts Investors From the Green Side
articles.snippet: Venture capital is moving away from alternative energy and returning to one of its traditional strengths: improving the efficiency of energy consumption.
articles.abstract: Venture capital is moving away from alternative energy and returning to one of its traditional strengths: improving the efficiency of energy consumption.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif.  In 2003, when Foundation Capital, a venture capital firm, started looking for new investors for Silver Spring Networks, one of its portfolio of companies, it was rejected by every firm it called.

articles.headline: Administration Plans to Strengthen Antitrust Rules
articles.snippet: The Obama administration plans to reverse a Bush administration policy shift that precluded antitrust actions against big corporations.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration plans to reverse a Bush administration policy shift that precluded antitrust actions against big corporations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s top antitrust official this week plans to restore an aggressive enforcement policy against corporations that use their market dominance to elbow out competitors or to keep them from gaining market share.

articles.headline: In Turnabout, Iran Releases U.S. Journalist
articles.snippet: An Iranian-American reporter who was jailed on spying charges was released after a court reduced the sentence.
articles.abstract: An Iranian-American reporter who was jailed on spying charges was released after a court reduced the sentence.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  An Iranian-American journalist sentenced to eight years in prison on charges of spying for the United States was released Monday, a legal turnabout that removes an obstacle to President Obama’s opening to Iran but illustrates the volatility of the Iranian government.
articles.byline: By Nazila Fathi and Mark Landler
